importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the news report reflects the current status of the flooding crisis, indicating ongoing humanitarian and governmental response efforts in Mexico.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The flooding events occurred over a period of time last week, highlighting the duration and scale of the disaster.

keyTakeAways: At least 64 people have died in Mexico due to heavy rains and flooding across five states.
The state of Veracruz reported 29 deaths, followed by 21 in Hidalgo, 13 in Puebla, and one in Queretaro.
Another 65 people are still missing, with 43 missing in Hidalgo, 18 in Veracruz, and 4 in Puebla.
The National Civil Protection Coordination (CNPC) chief, Laura Velazzquez Alzua, confirmed the death and missing tolls during a presidential briefing.
President Claudia Sheinbaum announced the deployment of thousands of military troops and coordination among governors to provide emergency assistance.
Early estimates show around 100,000 houses have been affected, with some properties near rivers reportedly 'practically disappeared'.
The flooding was caused by the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, leading to rapid river rises and landslides.
The heaviest rainfall occurred in Cerro Azul (Veracruz) and Cuetzalan del Progreso (Puebla), with 280mm and 286mm of rain respectively.
The Mexican Army, Air Force, and National Guard have jointly deployed to deliver food and clean water, especially to landslide-affected and road-blocked areas.
Nearly 400 repair workers have restored over 80% of electricity supply across five states, where about 263,000 users lost power.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Mexico has experienced a severe flooding disaster due to heavy rains from the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, resulting in at least 64 deaths and 65 people still missing across five states. The hardest-hit areas are Veracruz (29 deaths), Hidalgo (21 deaths), and Puebla (13 deaths). The National Civil Protection Coordination, led by Laura Velazquez Alzua, reported that over 100,000 homes were damaged, with some near rivers destroyed. President Claudia Sheinbaum announced a coordinated military response involving the Army, Air Force, and National Guard, who are delivering food and water to affected zones. The heaviest rains occurred in Cerro Azul and Cuetzalan del Progreso, with 280mm and 286mm of precipitation respectively. Nearly 400 repair workers have restored over 80% of electricity supply, which had been lost by around 263,000 users.
title: Mexico flooding death toll rises to 64, with dozens still missing
